cab.content: (THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HER BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)SECRETCbp,(56) 706th March, 195 capital punishment memorandum by the Secretary of State for the home department and Minister for Welsh affairs have been considering what form my speech should take in the Second Reading Debate on the Death Penalty (Abolition) Bill.It seems to me to be unnecessary and undesirable to reiterate thearguments which I put before the House in the Debate on 1 6th february and I propose, if my colleagues agree, to speak fairly late in the debate, to confine myself so far as the main issue is concerned tosaying that the Government remain of the opinion that capital punishmentought to be retained, but that I do not propose to repeat the arguments which I developed at some length in the Debate on 16th February,and to devote the rest of my speech to giving factual replies to any questions which may have been directed to the Government duringthe Debate.2. I should be glad to know whether my colleagues agree thatthis is the appropriate course to take.copy no. So-cabinet . LL-G.Home Office, S.W.1.5th March, 1956.
